children.text: 1. The world in spatial terms

a. Identifying and describing the characteristics and uses of geographic representations, such as various types of maps, globes, graphs, diagrams, photographs, and satellite-produced images (1, 3, 4);
b. Locating and interpreting geographic features and places on maps and globes (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Constructing maps, graphs, charts, and diagrams to describe geographical information and to solve problems (1, 3, 4);
a. Identifying and describing the characteristics, functions, and applications of various types of maps and other geographic representations, tools, and technologies (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Interpreting and developing maps, globes, graphs, charts, models, and databases to analyze spatial distributions and patterns (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Organizing and displaying information about the location of geographic features and places by using mental mapping skills (1, 2, 3, 4);
a. Using geographical representations, tools, and technologies to explain, analyze, and solve geographic problems (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Organizing geographic information and answering complex questions by formulating mental maps of places and regions (1, 2, 3, 4);
2. Places and regions
a. Describing and comparing the physical characteristics of places, including land forms, bodies of water, soils, vegetation, and climate (1, 3, 4);
b. Identifying and describing the human characteristics of places, including population distributions and culture (1, 3, 4);
c. Describing how the physical and human characteristics of places change over time (1, 3, 4);
d. Defining and differentiating regions by using physical characteristics, such as climate and land forms, and by using human characteristics, such as economic activity and language (1, 3, 4);
a. Explaining and analyzing both the physical and human phenomena associated with specific places, including precipitation and settlement patterns (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Identifying and describing significant physical features that have influenced historical events (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Identifying criteria used to define regions and explaining how and why regions change (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Describing and explaining how personal interests, culture, and technology affect people's perceptions and uses of places and regions (1, 2, 3, 4);
a. Determining how location and social, cultural, and economics processes affect the features and significance of places (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Analyzing the ways in which physical and human characteristics of places and regions have affected historic events (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Analyzing the various ways in which physical and human regions are structured and interconnected (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Explaining and evaluating the importance of places and regions to cultural identity (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
3. Physical and human systems
a. Describing how physical processes help to shape features and patterns on Earth's surface (1, 3, 4);
b. Describing and comparing the types of settlement and patterns of land use in local communities, the United States, and world regions (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Describing and explaining the characteristics, distribution, and migration of human populations (1, 3, 4);
d. Identifying and comparing the cultural characteristics of different regions and people (1, 2, 3, 4);
e. Locating and explaining the spatial distribution of economic activities (1, 3, 4);
f. Identifying and describing types of territorial units, such as parishes or counties, states, and countries (1, 3, 4, 5);
a. Prediction and explaining how physical features help to shape patterns and arrangements in the physical environment (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Identifying key demographic concepts and using these concepts to analyze the population characteristics of a country or region (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Describing the characteristics and patterns of human settlement in different regions of the world and analyzing the impact of urbanization (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Analyzing types, patterns, and effects of human migration over time (1, 2, 3, 4);
e. Tracing local and worldwide patterns of cultural diffusion and analyzing their causes and effects (1, 3, 4);
f. Comparing historical and contemporary patterns of economic interdependence (1, 2, 3, 4);
g. Explaining how cooperation and conflict among people contribute to the political divisions on Earth's surface (1, 2, 4);
a. Analyzing the ways in which Earth's dynamic and interactive physical processes affect different regions of the world (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Determining the economics, political, and social factors that contribute to human migration and settlement patterns and evaluating their impact on physical and human systems (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Analyzing trends in world population numbers and patterns and predicting their consequences (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Analyzing the characteristics, distribution, and interrelationships of the world's cultures (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Describing and evaluating spatial distributions of economics systems and how economic systems affect regions (1, 3);
f. Analyzing how cooperation, conflict, and self-interests impact social, political, and economic entities on Earth (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
4. Environment and society
a. Identifying and explaining ways in which people depend upon and modify the physical environment (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Describing how humans adapt to variations in the physical environment (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Describing the locations, causes and effects of natural disasters on the environment and society (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Describing the use, distribution, and importance of natural resources (1, 2, 3, 4, 5).
a. Analyzing and evaluating the effects of human actions upon the physical environment (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
b. Explaining and giving examples of how characteristics of different physical environments affect human activities (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Analyzing the worldwide distribution and utilization of natural resources (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
d. Identifying problems that relate to contemporary geographic issues and researching possible solutions (1, 2, 3, 4, 5).
a. Describing and evaluating the ways in which technology has expanded the human capability to modify the physical environment (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
b. Examining the challenges placed on human systems by the physical environment and formulating strategies to deal with these challenges (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Analyzing the relationship between natural resources and the exploration, colonization, settlement, and uses of land in different regions of the world (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
d. Evaluating policies and programs related to the use of natural resources (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Developing plans to solve local and regional geographic problems related to contemporary issues (1, 2, 3, 4, 5).
1. Structure and purposes of government
a. Describing government in terms of the people and groups who make, apply, and enforce rules and laws in the home, school, community, and nation (1, 3, 4, 5);
b. Explaining the necessity and basic purposes of government (1, 5);
c. Comparing limited governments to unlimited governments (1, 3);
d. Identifying and describing some of the major responsibilities of local, state, and national governments (1, 3, 5);
e. Identifying key members of government at the local, state, and national levels and describing their powers and the limits on their powers (1, 3, 5);
f. Explaining how officials in government acquire the authority to exercise political power (1, 5);
g. Explaining the purposes and importance of rules and laws (1, 2, 3, 5);
a. Explaining major ideas about why governments are necessary and evaluating competing positions on the purposes government should serve (1, 2, 4, 5);
b. Describing the essential characteristics of various systems of government (1, 3, 4, 5);
c. Explaining how the powers of the government are distributed, shared, and limited by the United States and Louisiana constitutions (1, 3, 5);
d. Explaining the purposes of state constitutions and describing the relationship of state constitutions to the federal constitution (1, 3, 5);
e. Describing the organization and major responsibilities of local, state, and national governments (1, 3, 5);
f. Identifying government leaders and representatives at the local, state, and national levels and explaining their powers and the limits on their powers (1, 3, 5);
g. Explaining the importance of law in the American constitutional system and applying criteria to evaluate rules and laws (, 2, 3, 4, 5);
h. Explaining how public policy is formed, debated, and carried out at local, state, and national levels (1, 3, 4, 5);
i. Explaining the necessity of taxes and describing the purposes for which tax revenues are used (1, 3, 4, 5);
j. Identifying and evaluating different types of taxes;
a. Analyzing the necessity and purposes of politics and government and identifying examples of programs that fit within those purposes (1, 2, 4, 5);
b. Comparing and evaluating the essential characteristics of various systems of government and identifying historical and contemporary examples of each (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Explaining and evaluating issues related to the distribution of powers and responsibilities within the federal system (1, 2, 4, 5);
d. Explaining the organization and functions of local, state, and national governments and evaluating their relationships (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Evaluating the role and importance of law in the American political system and applying criteria to evaluate laws (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
f. Examining the major responsibilities of the national government for domestic and foreign policy (1, 3, 4, 5);
g. Explaining how government is financed through taxation (1, 3, 4, 5);
2. Foundations of the American political system
a.  Identifying basic principles of American constitutional democracy and explaining how the constitutions of the United States and Louisiana reflect these principles (1, 3, 4, 5);
b. Discussing the importance of citizens' sharing and supporting the principles of American constitutional democracy (1, 3, 4, 5);
a. Explaining the essential ideas and historical origins of American constitutional government (1, 4, 5);
b. Identifying and describing the historical experiences and the geographic, social, and economic factors that have helped to shape American political culture (1, 3, 4, 5);
c. Explaining the meaning and importance of basic principles of American constitutional democracy as reflected in core documents (1, 3, 4, 5);
d. Analyzing the ways in which political and social conflict can be peacefully resolved (1, 2, 4, 5);
e. Analyzing democratic processes used to institute change (1, 2, 5);
f. Analyzing the importance of political parties, campaigns, and elections in the American political system (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
a. Analyzing the central ideas and historical origins of American constitutional government and evaluating how this form of government has helped to shaped American society (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);

b. Explaining basic democratic beliefs and principles of constitutional democracy in American society and applying them to the analysis of issues of conflicting beliefs and principles (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Analyzing the nature of American political and social conflict (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
d. Evaluating issues related to the differences between American ideals and the realities of American social and political life (1, 2, 4, 5);
e. Evaluating the roles of political parties, campaigns, and elections in American politics (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
f. Analyzing the historical and contemporary roles of associations and groups in local, state, and national politics (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
3. International relationships
a. Explaining that the world is divided into different nations and describing the major ways that these nations interact (1, 3, 4, 5);
a. Describing how the world is organized politically and explaining the means by which nation-states interact (1, 3, 4);
b. Explaining the formation, implementation, and impact of United States foreign policy (1, 3, 5);
c. Identifying types of foreign policy issues, using current and historical examples (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);

a. Analyzing how the world is organized politically and evaluating how the interaction of political entities, such as nation-states and international organizations, affects the United States (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
b. Analyzing the major foreign policy positions of the United States and evaluating their consequences (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Evaluating the impact of American ideas and actions on the world and analyzing the effects of significant international developments on the United States (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
4. Roles of the citizen
a. Explaining the meaning of citizenship and the means by which individuals become citizens of the United States (1, 3, 5);
b. Describing the rights and responsibilities of citizenship in a democratic society (1, 5);
c. Identifying and discussing civic traits that are important to the preservation and improvement of American constitutional democracy (1, 4, 5);
d. Describing the many ways that citizens can participate in and contribute to their communities and to American society (1, 2, 4, 5);
e. Discussing issues related to citizenship and public service (1, 3, 5).
a. Explaining the meaning of citizenship and the requirements for citizenship and naturalization in the United States (1, 5);
b. Identifying the rights and responsibilities of citizens and explaining their importance to the individual and to society (1, 4, 5);
c. Discussing issues involving the rights and responsibilities of individuals in American society (1, 2, 4, 5);
d. Describing the many ways by which citizens can organize, monitor, and help to shape politics and government at local, state, and national levels (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Communicating the importance of knowledge to competent and responsible political participation and leadership (1, 4, 5);
a. Evaluating and defending positions on issues regarding the personal, political, and economics rights of citizens (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
b. Evaluating and defending positions regarding the personal and civic responsibilities and citizens in American constitutional democracy (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
c. Explaining and evaluating the various forms of political participation that citizens can use to monitor and shape the formation and implementation of public policy (1, 2, 4, 5);
d. Analyzing and evaluating the importance of political leadership, public service, and a knowledgeable citizenry to American constitutional democracy (1, 2, 4, 5);
1. Fundamental economic concepts
a. Recognizing that limited resources require people to make decisions (1, 2, 4);
b. Identifying what is gained and lost when individuals or groups make decisions (1, 3, 4, 5);
c. Demonstrating how economic wants affect decisions about using goods and services (1, 2, 4);
d. Discussing and determining the process for making economic decisions (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Explaining the relationships among producers and consumers (1, 4);
f. Describing how natural resources, human resources, and capital (human-made) resources have been used and are combined in the production of goods and services (1, 3, 4);
g. Describing how specialization affects productivity and contributes to the need for interdependence among producers and consumers (1, 4);
h. Determining how the development of skills and knowledge relates to career opportunity and economic well-being (1, 4, 5);
i. Identifying different methods for the distribution of goods and services, including the concept of markets (1, 4, 5);
j. Identifying some of the economic institutions, such as households and banks, that make up the economy (1, 4);
k. Explaining and demonstrating why people participate in voluntary exchanges and how money helps in the process (1, 2, 4, 5);
a. Describing how the scarcity of resources necessitates decision making at both person and societal levels (1, 2, 4, 5);
b. Analyzing consequences of economic decisions in terms of additional benefits and additional costs (1, 2, 4);
c. Analyzing the consequences and opportunity cost of economic decisions (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Analyzing the role of specialization in the economic process (1, 2, 4);
e. Giving examples of how skills and knowledge increase productivity and career opportunities (1, 3, 4, 5);
f. Describing the essential differences in the production and allocation of goods and services in traditional, command, and market systems;
g. Describing the various institutions, such as business firms and government agencies, that make up economic systems (1, 4);
h. Differentiating among various forms of exchange and money (1, 3, 4);
i. Using economic concepts to help explain historic and contemporary events and developments (1, 2, 3, 4);
a. Analyzing the impact of the scarcity of productive resources and examining the choices and opportunity cost that result (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
b. Analyzing the roles that production, distribution, and consumption play in economic decisions (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Applying the skills and knowledge necessary in making decisions about career options (2, 3, 4, 5);
d. Comparing and evaluating economic systems (1, 2, 3, 4);
e. Explaining the basic features of market structures and exchanges (1, 3, 4);
f. Analyzing the roles of economic institutions, such as corporations and labor unions, that compose economic systems (1, 2, 4);
g. Analyzing the roles of money and banking in an economic system (1, 2, 3, 4);
h. Applying economic concepts to understand and evaluate historical and contemporary issues (1, 2, 3, 4);
2. Individuals, households, businesses, and governments
a. Describing how prices are determined by the interactions of buyers and sellers (1, 3, 4);
b. Explaining how the changes in prices affect incentives to produce, consume, and save (1, 3, 4);
c. Identifying and explaining economic concepts, such as profit as an incentive for people to take economic risk (1, 2, 4);
d. Explaining why some goods and services are provided by the government through taxing, charging user fees, and borrowing (1, 3, 4, 5);
e. Identifying the major goods and services produces in the local community and state (1, 3, 5).
a. Explaining the role of supply and demand in a competitive market system (1, 3, 4);
b. Explaining the factors that affect the production and distribution of goods and services (1, 4);
c. Explaining the difference between private and public goods and services (1, 4, 5);
d. Identifying the costs and benefits of government policies on competitive markets (1, 3, 4, 5);
e. Identifying different types of taxes and user fees and predicting their consequences (1, 3, 4, 5);
f. Determining the reasons for trade between nations, identifying costs and benefits, and recognizing the worldwide interdependence that results (1, 4);
g. Describing historical and economic factors that have contributed to the development and growth of the national, state, and local economies (1, 3, 4, 5);
a. Identifying factors that cause changes in supply and demand (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Analyzing how changes in supply and demand, price, incentives, and profit influence production and distribution in a competitive market system (1, 2, 4);
c. Analyzing the impact of governmental taxation, spending, and regulation on different groups in a market economy (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
d. Analyzing the causes and consequences of worldwide economic interdependence (1, 2, 3, 4);
e. Evaluating the effects of domestic policies on international trade (1, 2, 3, 4);
f. Analyzing Louisiana's role in the national and world economies (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
3. The economy as a whole
a. Explaining the meaning of economic indicators that help to describe economies (1, 3);
b. Describing the influences of inflation, unemployment, and underemployment on different groups of people (1, 4, 5).
a. Explaining the meanings of such economic indicators as GDP, per capita GDP, real GDP, CPI, and unemployment rate (1, 3, 4);
b. Explaining how interest rates, investments, and inflation/deflation impact the economy (1, 3, 4);
c. Analyzing the causes and consequences of unemployment, underemployment, and income distribution in a market economy (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Explaining the basic concepts of United States fiscal policy, monetary policy, and regulations and describing their effects on the economy (1, 3, 4);
1. Historical thinking skills
a. Demonstrating an understanding of the concepts of time and chronology (1, 3, 4);
b. Recognizing that people in different times and places view the world differently (1, 3, 4);
c. Identifying and using primary and secondary historical sources to learn about the past (1, 3, 4);
a. Describing chronological relationships and patterns (1, 3, 4);
b. Demonstrating historical perspective through the political, social and economic context in which an event or idea occurred (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Analyzing the impact that specific individuals, ideas, events, and decisions had on the course of history (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Analyzing historical data using primary and secondary sources (1, 2, 3, 4);
e. Identifying issues and problems from the past and evaluating alternative courses of action (1, 2, 3, 4);
f. Conducting research in efforts to answer historical questions (1, 2, 3, 4);
a. Applying key concepts, such as chronology and conflict, to explain and analyze patterns of historical change and continuity (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Explaining and analyzing events, ideas, and issues within a historical context (1, 2, 3, 4);
c. Interpreting and evaluating the historical evidence presented in primary and secondary sources (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Utilizing knowledge of facts and concepts drawn from history and methods of historical inquiry to analyze historical and contemporary issues (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
e. Conducting research in efforts to analyze historical questions and issues (1, 2, 3, 4);
f. Analyzing cause-effect relationships (1, 2, 3, 4);
2. Families and communities
a. Describing and comparing family life in the present and the past (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Relating the history of the local community and comparing it to other communities of long ago (1, 2, 3, 4);
3. Louisiana and United States history
a. Describing the people, events, and ideas that were significant to the growth and development of our state and nation (1, 3, 4);
b. Identifying the development of democratic principles and discussing how these principles have been exemplified by historic figures, events, and symbols (1, 3, 4, 5);
c. Describing the causes and nature of various movements of large groups of people into and within Louisiana and the United States throughout history (1, 3, 4);
d. Recognizing how folklore and other cultural elements have contributed to our local, state, and national heritage (1, 3, 4);
4. World history
a. Identifying the characteristics and historical development of selected societies throughout the world (1, 3, 4);
b. Describing the social and economic impact of major scientific and technological advancements (1, 3, 4);
c. Discussing the impact of significant contributions made by historic figures from different regions of the world (1, 3, 4);
2. United States History
a. Era 1: Three Worlds Meet (Beginnings to 1620)
i. Identifying and describing characteristics of societies in the Americas, Western Europe, and Western Africa that increasingly interacted after 1450 (1, 3, 4);
ii. Explaining the cultural, ecological, and economic results of early European exploration and colonization (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the significant changes that resulted from interactions among the peoples of Europe, Africa, and the Americas (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Era 2: Colonization and Settlement (1565-1763)
i. Describing the interactions among Native Americans, early Europeans, and Africans in the Americas (1, 3, 4);
ii. Tracing the emergence of religious freedom and changing political institutions in the English colonies (1, 3, 4);
iii. Analyzing the impact of European cultural, political, and economic ideas and institutions on life in the Americas (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Summarizing the process by which the United States was colonized and later became an independent nation (1, 4);
c. Era 3: Revolution and the New Nation (1754- 1820s)
i. Explaining the causes and course of the American Revolution and the reasons for the American victory (1, 3, 4);
ii. Explaining the impact of the American Revolution on the politics, society, and economy of the new nation (1, 3, 4);
iii. Relating the institutions and practices of government established during and after the American Revolution to the foundation of the American political system (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the development of the American constitutional system (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Era 4: Expansion and Reform (1801-1861)
i. Describing the territorial expansion of the United States and analyzing the effects on relations with Native Americans and external powers (1, 3, 4, 5);

ii. Analyzing the changes and regional tensions created by Jacksonian democracy, the industrial revolution, increasing immigration, the rapid expansion of slavery, and the westward movement (1, 2, 3, 4);
iii. Explaining and giving examples of the reform movements that occurred during the antebellum period and evaluating their impact on American society (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
i. Tracing territorial expansion and reform movements in the United States (1, 3, 4);
e. Era 5: Civil War and Reconstruction (1850-1877)
i. Describing the causes and course of the Civil War and examining the impact of the war on the American people (1, 3, 4);
ii. Comparing and evaluating various reconstruction plans of the post-Civil War era (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the origins, major events, and effects of the Civil War and Reconstruction (1, 2, 3, 4);
f. Era 6: The Development of the Industrial United States (1870-1900)
i. Describing the impact of industrialization in the United States (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the development of industrialization and examining its impact on American society (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Describing the immigration and internal migration patterns that have occurred in the history of the United States and examining the cultural and social changes that have resulted (1, 2, 3, 4);
g. Era 7: The Emergence of Modern America (1890-1930)
i. Describing the significant economic, political, social, and cultural changes that have occurred in the United States during the 20th century (1, 3, 4);
ii. Identifying the causes and consequences of major world conflicts involving the United States (1, 3, 4);
i. Evaluating the significance of the Progressive Movement (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Analyzing the rise of the labor and agrarian movements (1, 2, 3, 4);
iii. Explaining the changing role of the United States in world affairs through World War I (1, 3, 4);
iv. Analyzing the significant changes that evolved in the United States between World War I and the Great Depression (1, 2, 3, 4);
h. Era 8: The Great Depression and World War II (1929-1945)
i. Describing the impact of the Great Depression and World War II on American society (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the causes, developments, and effects of the Great Depression and the New Deal (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Analyzing the origins, course, and results of World War II (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Era 9: Contemporary United States (1945 to the Present)
i. Discussing significant developments and issues in contemporary United States history (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
i. Examining and summarizing key developments and issues in foreign and domestic policies during the Cold War era (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Analyzing the economic, political, social, and cultural transformation of the United States since World War II (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
iii. Explaining the major changes that have resulted as the United States has moved from an industrial to an information society (1, 3, 4);
iv. Analyzing developments and issues in contemporary American society (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
v. Discussing and demonstrating an understanding of recent developments in foreign and domestic policies (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
3. World History
a. Era 1: The Beginnings of Society
i. Describing the earliest human communities (1, 3, 4);
ii. Explaining the emergence of agricultural societies around the world (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the development of early human communities and civilizations (1, 2, 3, 4);
b. Era 2: The Rise of Early Civilization (4000-1000 B.C.)
i. Identifying the major characteristics of early civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus valley (1, 3, 4);
ii. Tracing the development and expansion of agricultural societies and the emergence of new states (1, 3, 4);
iii. Analyzing the political, social, and cultural consequences of population movements and militarization in Europe and Asia (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Making generalizations about the cultural legacies of both the ancient river and the classical civilizations (1, 3, 4);
c. Era 3: Classical Traditions, Major Religions, and Giant Empires (1000 B.C.-A.D. 300)
i. Discussing and giving examples of technological and cultural innovation and change (1, 3, 4);
ii. Describing the classical civilizations and examining their interactions and influences (1, 3, 4);
iii. Describing and comparing the emergence of major religions and large-scale empires in the Mediterranean basin, China, and India (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the origins, central ideas, and worldwide impact of major religious and philosophical traditions (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Era 4: Expanding Zones of Exchange and Encounter (A.D. 300-1000)
i. Tracing the expansion of major religions and cultural traditions and examining the impact on civilizations in Europe, Asia, and Africa (1, 3, 4);
ii. Analyzing the political, social, and cultural developments and changes that resulted from the rise and fall of empires and kingdoms in Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Summarizing the developments and contributions of civilizations that flourished in Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas (1, 3, 4);
e. Era 5: Intensified Hemispheric Interactions (A.D. 1000-1500)
i. Analyzing the cultural and economic impact of the interregional system of communication and trade that developed among the peoples of Europe, Asia, and Africa (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Explaining the developments and events that led to the political, social, cultural, and economic transformation of Europe (1, 3, 4);
iii. Describing the development and expansion of complex societies and empires in the Americas (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the consequences of the economic and cultural interchange that increasingly developed among the peoples of Europe, Asia, and Africa (1, 2, 3, 4);
f. Era 6: Emergence of the First Global Age (1450- 1770)

i. Explaining the political, cultural, and economic developments and trends of major world regions that resulted in the transformation of societies in the 15th through the mid-18th centuries (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the impact of transoceanic linking of all major regions of the world (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Analyzing the political, cultural, and economic developments and trends that resulted in the transformation of major world regions (1, 2, 3, 4);
iii. Explaining how the emergence of territorial empires in Europe, Asia, and Africa unified large areas politically, economically, and culturally (1, 3, 4);
iv. Tracing the expansion of European power and economic influence in the world and examining the impact of this expansion on societies in Asia and the Americas (1, 3, 4);
g. Era 7: An Age of Revolutions (1750-1914)
i. Determining and discussing the impact of the political, agricultural, and industrial revolutions on societies around the world (1, 3, 4);
ii. Describing the transformation of world societies that occurred during an era of global trade and Western domination (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the impact that political revolutions and new ideologies had on societies around the world (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Evaluating the economic, political, and social consequences of the agricultural and industrial revolutions on world societies (1, 2, 3, 4);
iii. Analyzing the patterns of worldwide change that emerged during the era of Western military and economic domination (1, 2, 3, 4);
h. Era 8: A Half-Century of Crisis and Achievement (1900-1945)
i. Identifying the causes and worldwide consequences of major 20th century conflicts (1, 3, 4);
i. Analyzing the causes and international consequences of World War I, the rise and actions of totalitarian systems, World War II, and other early 20th century conflicts (1, 2, 3, 4);
i. Era 9: The 20th Century Since 1945 (1945 to the Present)
i. Identifying and discussing significant political, economic, social, cultural, and technological trends that have had an impact on the modern world (1, 3, 4, 5);
i. Analyzing the international power shifts and the breakup of colonial empires that occurred in the years following World War II (1, 2, 3, 4);
ii. Explaining the worldwide significance of major political, economic, social, cultural, and technological developments and trends (1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
4. Louisiana History
a. Describing the contributions of people, events, movements, and ideas that have been significant in the history of Louisiana (1, 3, 4);
b. Tracing the development of the various governments that have been established in Louisiana throughout its history (1, 3, 4, 5);
c. Identifying and discussing the major conflicts in Louisiana's past (1, 2, 3, 4);
d. Locating and describing Louisiana's geographic features and examining their impact on people past and present (1, 3, 4);
